results.title: Lion - tiger fight! (D)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Adventure parade”.
A pre World War II edited news/show-reel, a dramatic and adventurous expedition into the wild jungles of India. Mostly contrived and very little adherance to actual fact. The pith-helmeted hunters eventually capture a tiger and…a lion! They soberly watch on as the two cats fight to the death. NB: SOME SCENES MAY DISTURB

results.title: Lion
results.creator_credit: John Downer, BBC and Discovery Channel
results.brief_description: A state-of-the-art remote-control camera disguised as a boulder is the innovative filming technique used to get filmmakers to the very heart of a pride of lions. For the first time a litter of cubs is filmed from the time they are introduced by the lionness to the rest of the pride at 6 weeks, covering almost 3,000 hours of growing time, until they are mature adults. Through this time David Attenborough discusses significant events in the development of the young lions that turn them from cubs into proficient hunters. This is a unique insight into the development of lions and the main discovery made is that every skill an adult lion has, every move it makes, is learned and practiced as a cub. Michael W. Richards and Geoffrey Bell are the main cinematographers who allow us to go where no camera has ever gone before.

results.title: Lintola: addition with carrying
results.creator_credit: Davidson Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

Episode of Series “Math that counts”.
Introduces two-digit addition problems, particularly problems which require regrouping. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Linnaeus
results.brief_description: The life of Linnaeus, the Swedish botanist, re-enacted against the Swedish landscape. His birthplace, studies at Uppsala University and the first journey to Lappland. Studies in Holland and first publication of the “Systema Naturae”. Its place in scientific history. His later work as a teacher and in making surveys of Sweden’s natural resources. The Linnaen museum. Includes many close-ups of Swedish flowers and animals.

results.title: Link span
results.creator_credit: Edgar H. Anstey, British Transport Films and Michael Clarke
results.brief_description: Twenty-four hours in the operation of the British Railways cross-channel ferry services, which join the roads and railways of Britain with those of Europe. The SS Lord Warden is seen carrying between Dover and Boulogne as many as 130 cars and a thousand passengers. A freight train ferry plies between Zeebrugge and Harwich loaded with fruit from the Mediterranean. A third example is that of the Night Train Ferry which takes its sleeping passengers direct from London to Paris.

results.title: Link-up diary
results.creator_credit: AIAS Film Unit and David MacDougall
results.brief_description: An extraordinary personal journey into the experience of being black in a powerful white society. “Link-up Diary” is a film about the consequences of New South Wales long term practice of taking Aboriginal children away from their parents and raising them in “white” environments. In following the reunification, after many years, of several families in Sydney, during one week of 1986, the filmmaker adopts a diary format which does not attempt to disguise awareness of the camera’s presence. This awareness becomes part of the film’s subject.

results.title: Linguistics and education (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: WRC-TV Productions, Richard Ahearn, Stuart Finley and John Kinnamon
results.brief_description: Some educators hold views about language which limit their effectiveness in teaching standard English. Having eaten our lunch, the steamboat departed produces a wrong response resulting in a break down in communication. It is in fact a more serious error than are dialectal divergences which produce social reactions but communicate effectively.

results.title: Lingiari: until the chains are removed
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and John Smith
results.brief_description: The annual Vincent Lingiari Memorial Lectures are given in honour of Vincent Lingiari, an Aboriginal activist of the Gurindji tribe who died in 1988, to pay homage to his inspirational leadership in what we now know as the Aboriginal land rights movement. This 4th memorial lecture is delivered by Patrick “Pat” Dodson, the well known former chair of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and one of the senior leaders of Aboriginal Australia. Pat has been a football player, a former Catholic priest, a Commissioner with the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, and a negotiator for Aboriginal rights. He speaks about recognition for, and reconciliation with, the Australian indigenous peoples by non-indigenous peoples; recognition of Aboriginal rights to the land, not as tenants, but as owners and custodians of the land; the stolen generations and an apology with a meaning; self-determination and a right to justice, equality and a shared future with all Australians.

results.title: Lines vertical
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, ONF | NFB and Evelyn Lambart
results.brief_description: An experiment in pure design by film artists Norman McLaren and Evelyn Lambart. Lines ruled directly on the film move with precision and grace against a background of changing colours, in response to music composed by and played by Maurice Blackburn on the electronic piano. No commentary, music only.
